Summary: This is a coordinated entry location for homeless youth ages 18-24 to receive housing assessments and support, and shelter referrals.
Services:
- Problem solving services
- Housing assessment and prioritization
Program About: In partnership with SF HSH, Dolores Community Services is a designated Coordinated Entry (CE) Access Point for homeless youth (aged 18 to 24 years old) to find permanent supportive housing and rapid re-housing in San Francisco.
Organization About: Dolores Street Community Services helps low-income and immigrant communities for a fairer society. They provide housing, shelter, and support. They also fight for women's and immigrant rights and have a community engagement program.
Application Details: Drop-in at 2645 Mission Street to receive a housing assessment.
Open Hours: Monday-Friday: 9:00 AM-5:00 PM (Wednesday: closes at 3:30 PM)

Summary: This is a coordinated entry location for youth under 27 to receive housing assessments for shelter referrals, alongside educational/employment support and health/wellness/hygiene services.
Services:
- Shelter
- Case Management
- Educational Support/Referrals
- Employment Support/Referrals
- Wellness Services
- Health Services
- Hygiene Services
- Community Activities
- Population served: Youth under 27
Program About: Youth Coordinated Entry is provided for youth under the age of 27 via Access Points and via a mobile team that can attend to individual needs where they are located. A CONNECTION to an available youth shelter.
Organization About: Larkin Street Youth Services provides shelter, meals, medical services, and intensive case management to youth aged 12 to 25 years.
Application Details: Drop-in between 10:00 AM and 3:00 PM or schedule an appointment by call to receive a housing assessment.

Summary: This is a coordinated entry location for homeless LGBTQ youth ages 18-24 to receive housing assessments and support, and shelter referrals.
Services:
- Problem solving services
- Housing assessment and prioritization
Program About: In partnership with SF HSH, LYRIC is a designated Coordinated Entry (CE) Access Point for homeless LGBTQ youth (aged 18 to 24 years old) to find permanent supportive housing and rapid re-housing in San Francisco.
Organization About: LYRIC’s mission is to build community and inspire positive social change through education enhancement, career trainings, health promotion, and leadership development with LGBTQ youth, their families, and allies of all races, classes, genders, and abilities.
Application Details: Drop-in Monday to Thursday or call to schedule an appointment to receive a housing assessment.

Summary: This is a coordinated entry location for homeless LGBTQ youth ages 18-27 to receive housing assessments and support, and shelter referrals.
Services:
- Problem-Solving support: help with housing location, flexible financial support, and relocation/travel assistance
- Housing assessments and case management
- Referral to other community services
- Connection to available shelter
Program About: The SF LGBT Center is a Coordinated Entry Access Point for LGBTQ youth (aged 18 to 27 years old) who are experiencing homelessness or will lose their housing within 14 days.
Organization About: Since 2002, the San Francisco LGBT Community Center (SF LGBT Center) is a non-profit organization in San Francisco that serves members of the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender communities. SF LGBT Center has programs that provide LGBTQ individuals access to opportunities and resources for them to heal and thrive.
Application Details: Drop-in Tuesday or Wednesday from 12:00 PM to 5:00 PM or call to schedule an appointment for online services to receive a housing assessment.

Program Name: Youth Housing and Shelter Resources - Bayview
Summary: This is a coordinated entry location for homeless youth ages 18-27 to receive housing assessments for shelter referrals, alongside employment/healthcare/legal services and internet/computer access.
Services:
- Community Engagement
- Employment Services
- Healthcare & Mental Health
- Legal and Social services
- Internet/Computer Access
- Peer Resource Navigation
Program About: 3rd Street Youth Center is a Coordinated Entry Access Point for youth (aged 18 to 27 years) who are experiencing homelessness or are at risk of homelessness
Organization About: The 3rd Street Youth Center and Clinic is a community based agency providing youth in Bayview Hunters Point with medical and behavioral health services that encourage them to make decisions that support their health, safety and development.
Application Details: Call to schedule an appointment or leave a voicemail with your name, contact information, and preferred language to receive a housing assessment.

Summary: This is an 8-week emergency shelter for women and children experiencing domestic violence with access to counseling and support groups.
Services:
- Onsite 24-hour staff to ensure safety and support
- Individual counseling
- Support groups
- Practical living skills development
- Resource Advocacy
- Support service referrals
Program About: La Casa De Las Madres has a safe, confidentially-located emergency shelter for women and children experiencing domestic violence to stay for up to 8 weeks.
Organization About: Since 1976, La Casa de las Madres has been responding to calls for help from domestic violence victims, of all ages, 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. Through their 24-hour toll-free crisis & support hotlines, text line and drop-in center, La Casa gives survivors the tools they need to transform their lives. They seek to prevent future violence by educating the community and by redefining public perceptions about  domestic violence.
Application Details: Call or text with the numbers below for further instructions.

Summary: This is a shelter for surviviors of domestic violence with emergency services like food and clothing and support services like transportation and counseling.
Services:
- Safe, confidential shelter with bed capacity of 15-18 people, including children
- Emergency services (food, clothing and ongoing health services)
- Multilingual support and culturally competent services
- Intensive case management
- Individual and group support
- Coordination of support services (legal advocacy and assistance, transportation, counseling, training/employment, and mentoring)
- Follow-up services, including resources to establish permanent or transitional housing
Program About: AWS serves all women survivors of domestic violence and human trafficking and their families
Organization About: San Francisco's Asian Women's Shelter helps survivors of domestic violence and human trafficking. Services offer long-term solutions to ending homelessness, poverty and domestic violence with a holistic, survivor-centered approach that strives to be both linguistically and culturally competent. Services are provided in 41 languages.
Application Details: Call with the number below for further instructions.

Program Name: Young Adult Temporary Hotel Voucher Program
Summary: This program provides youth ages 18-27 with a hotel voucher for 14 days, alongisde links to longer-term housing solutions.
Services:
- Emergency shelter
- Case management.
- Linkage to housing problem solving and assessment
- Employment services
- Benefit assistance
- Help obtaining critical documents (birth certificates, State ID, Social Security Card)
- Other individualized supports based on identified needs
Program About: St. Vincent de Paul Society’s Young Adult Temporary Hotel Voucher Program (also called Urgent Accommodation Voucher program, or UAV) assists young people ages 18-27 who are experiencing an emergency or do not have access to a traditional shelter by providing them with a hotel voucher for up to 14 days.
Organization About: The St. Vincent de Paul Society of San Francisco was established in 1860 on a simple principle: assist those who need help the most. Whether it be through financial support, emotional or spiritual guidance, or by providing basic necessities such as food and shelter, we strive to offer our clients with a sense of hope during their darkest hours.
Application Details: Call with the numbers below to see if you are eligible.

Organization Name: San Francisco Department of Homelessness and Supportive Housing
Summary: This program allows homeless adults to sign up for an overnight shelter bed.
Services: - Overnight shelter bed
Program About: Sign up for the adult shelter reservation waitlist for a bed at three of HSH’s sites
Organization About: The Department of Homelessness and Supportive Housing (HSH) launched on July 1, 2016. The department combines key homeless-serving programs and contracts from the Department of Public Health (DPH), the Human Services Agency (HSA), the Mayor’s Office of Housing and Community Development (MOHCD), and the Department of Children Youth and Their Families (DCYF). This consolidated department has a singular focus on preventing and ending homelessness for people in San Francisco.
Application Details: Either fill our this form (https://sanfrancisco.form.us.empro.verintcloudservices.com/form/auto/hsh_shelter_reservation) which asks for name, birthdate, email, phone, and shelter preferences OR call with the number below.

Summary: This is an emergency shelter for individuals to receive a nutrious meal, a warm bed, and a clean shower.
Services:
- Nutrious meal
- Warm bed
- Clean shower
Program About: For families and individuals looking to escape extreme weather or just wanting a safe, quiet place to spend the night, emergency shelters provide a nutritious meal, a warm bed and a clean shower to those in need.
Organization About: The Salvation Army, an international movement, is an evangelical part of the universal Christian Church. Its message is based on the Bible. Its ministry is motivated by the love of God. Its mission is to preach the gospel of Jesus Christ and to meet human needs in His name without discrimination.
Application Details: Drop-in Monday - Friday at 1275 Harrison Street before 5:00 PM to receive shelter for the night.

Summary: This is a 12-week emergency shelter for individuals experiencing domestic violence, including counseling, housing support, and education/employment support.
Services:
- Safety Planning
- One-on-One Counseling
- Support Groups
- Case Management
- Parenting Groups
- Legal Assistance
- Employment/Education Referrals
- Housing Search Assistance
Program About: Our 23 bed emergency shelter offers those fleeing from violence or other forms of domestic abuse a safe, temporary haven for up to 12 weeks. In addition to providing food and shelter, Rosalie House provides residents with other means of support.
Organization About: The St. Vincent de Paul Society of San Francisco was established in 1860 on a simple principle: assist those who need help the most. Whether it be through financial support, emotional or spiritual guidance, or by providing basic necessities such as food and shelter, we strive to offer our clients with a sense of hope during their darkest hours.
Application Details: Call the number below for further instructions.

Summary: This a 12-month transitional housing program for women experiencing domestic violence, with ongoing support for emotional/financial independence.
Services:
- Secure, positive living environment for up to 12 months
- Ongoing support and focus on becoming emotionally and financially independent
Program About: Our 31 bed transitional housing program provides women and their children a secure, positive living environment for up to 12 months. At Brennan House, women have the opportunity to continue the healing process with ongoing support and focus on making concrete steps towards obtaining emotional and financial self-sufficiency.
Organization About: The St. Vincent de Paul Society of San Francisco was established in 1860 on a simple principle: assist those who need help the most. Whether it be through financial support, emotional or spiritual guidance, or by providing basic necessities such as food and shelter, we strive to offer our clients with a sense of hope during their darkest hours.
Application Details: Call the number below for further instructions.

Summary: This is a drop-in location for a safe space during the day (bathroom, shower, laundry), and access to shelter reservations.
Services:
- Safe space during the day and access to bathrooms, showers, and laundry services
- Peer counseling
- Case management
- Shelter reservations
- Lockers
- Community building activities
Program About: Founded in 2002 as a community response to the neighborhood’s growing homeless population, the Mission Neighborhood Resource Center (MNRC) advocates for housing and resources to enhance the physical, social, emotional and economic health of homeless residents in the 16th street corridor and surrounding Mission neighborhood. MNRC employs a service model based on harm-reduction principles and practices that focus on community building, basic human needs, and integrated health services for a diverse population as they move toward greater stability and well being. MNRC offers services that are bilingual, free of charge and available on a drop-in basis.
Organization About: Mission Neighborhood Health Center honors our Latino roots with a tradition of providing compassionate, patient-centered care.  We advocate for health equity and deliver innovative, high quality services responsive to the neighborhoods and diverse communities we serve.
Application Details: Drop-in at 165 Capp Street and ask for help with shelter reservations.
Open Hours: Monday - Friday: 7:00 AM - 12:00 PM, 2:00 - 5:00 PM. Saturday: 7:00 AM - 11:00 AM

Summary: This is a drop-in location for access to basic needs like hygiene and clothing, alongside help with shelter reservations and rental assitance.
Services:
- Shelter reservations
- Rental assistance
- Case management
- Access to hygiene items, clothing, and other household items as available
- Notary public services
- COVID testing and vaccinations
Program About: The GLIDE Walk-In Center is a place where basic needs are met immediately. We provide assistance in obtaining immediate needs like shelter, hygiene and emotional support in an atmosphere of respect and compassion for all those who come through our doors.
Organization About: GLIDE is a nationally recognized center for social justice, dedicated to fighting systemic injustices, creating pathways out of poverty and crisis, and transforming lives.
Application Details: Drop-in at 330 Ellis Street and ask for help with shelter reservations.

Summary: This is an educational/employment housing program for youth ages 18-24 to build self-sufficiency skills.
Services:
- Fully subsidized housing during duration of program
- Completion of a High School Diploma or GED certificate
- Enrollment in post-secondary education or vocational training program
- Completion of industry-recognized certificates
- Seeking and securing sustainable living-wage employment
- Education planning, course selection and tutoring
- Financial aid and scholarship applications
- Leveraging existing on-campus resources
- Job search and job retention strategies
- Resume and cover letter writing
- Workplace readiness skill-building
- Career counseling
Program About: My First Place is a nationally recognized education and employment program providing housing and case management for foster youth between ages 18 and 24. Supporting foster youth entering adulthood with jobs that earn a living wage, this program fosters a sense of permanency and stability while building skills to be self-sufficient long-term.
Organization About: First Place for Youth helps foster youth build the skills they need to make a successful transition to self-sufficiency and responsible adulthood.
Application Details: Fill out this form (https://firstplaceforyouth.org/youth-interest-and-referral-form/) to express interest and await for further instructions.

Summary: This is a coordinated entry site for housing assessments, problem-solving, and shelter referrals.
Services:
- Housing problem solving
- Housing assessments
- Linkage to resources
Program About: Housing Resource Centers (HRC) coordinate County and local resources to connect high-needs people with housing. HRCs are a point of entry for the Coordinated Entry System in Alameda County. All visitors can access housing problem solving, assessments, and linkage to resources.
Organization About: BACS envisions strong neighborhoods where everyone is healthy and has an abundance of resources, meaningful relationships, and a place they call home.
Application Details: Either drop-in or call at the given hours to receive a housing assessment.
Open Hours: Monday - Thursday: 9:00 AM - 12:00 PM (drop-in), call anytime

Summary: This is a coordinated entry site for housing assessments, problem-solving, and shelter referrals.
Services:
- Needs assessments
- Housing education
- Access to listings
- Advocacy with landlords
- Help filling out housing applications
- Connection to subsidies as available
- Case management
Program About: A highly skilled and trained team of Housing Navigators provides needs assessments, housing education, access to listings, advocacy with landlords, help filling out housing applications, connection to subsidies as available, and case management to facilitate a successful transition to housing along with critical time intervention to ensure stabilization. The team understands the intertwined issues facing individuals and families in deep poverty and connects them to wrap-around services and community assets as appropriate.
Organization About: BOSS was created in 1971 to help individuals with severe and persistent mental illness who had become displaced because of public hospital closures. Programs and services expanded over the past five decades to include services for unhoused, disabled, and low-income individuals, families, and neighborhoods in Alameda County.
Application Details: Either drop-in or call at the given hours to receive a housing assessment.
Open Hours: Weekdays except Wednesday: 10:00 AM - 2:00 PM (drop-in), Monday - Friday: 9:00 AM - 5:00 PM (call)

Summary: This is a coordinated entry site for housing assessments, problem-solving, and shelter referrals.
Services:
- Help through housing search and application
- Financial assistance for move-in
- Support ability to sustainably stay a tenant
Program About: Serving MediCal-eligible individuals through housing search and application processes, financial assistance for move-in, and supporting their ability to sustainably stay a tenant — in partnership with Alameda County’s CES
Organization About: EOCP empowers individuals and families who are homeless in Alameda County to regain a life of self-reliance. We provide dignified emergency and transitional housing and compassionate, comprehensive support services that prepare homeless people to successfully transition to well-being and sustainable permanent housing.
Application Details: Either drop-in or call at the given hours to receive a housing assessment.
Open Hours: Thursday, Friday: 10:00 AM - 3:00 PM (drop-in), call anytime

Summary: This is a coordinated entry site for housing assessments, problem-solving, and shelter referrals.
Services:
- Housing problem solving
- Housing assessments
- Linkage to resources
Program About: Housing Resource Centers (HRC) coordinate County and local resources to connect high-needs people with housing. HRCs are a point of entry for the Coordinated Entry System in Alameda County. All visitors can access housing problem solving, assessments, and linkage to resources.
Organization About: BACS envisions strong neighborhoods where everyone is healthy and has an abundance of resources, meaningful relationships, and a place they call home.
Application Details: Either drop-in or call at the given hours to receive a housing assessment.
Open Hours: Monday, Wednesday, Friday: 9:00 AM - 12:00 PM (drop-in), call anytime

Summary: This is a drop-in center for women to receive hot meals, groceries, and hygiene products, alongside housing assessments for shelter referrals.
Services:
- Hot meals
- Groceries
- Hygiene products
- Housing resource services
Program About: Our drop-in services are available Monday through Friday 9am - 1pm.  During this time, we offer hot meals, groceries, and hygiene products to women and children in need through our service window. WDDC offers housing resource services to unhoused participants over the phone by calling (510) 548-2884.  We are also the North Country Housing Resource Center (serving Berkeley, Albany and Emeryville families).
Organization About: Homelessness takes on many forms. Often, it's the result of domestic violence, chronic illness, loss of employment and/or the inability to make ends meet. Not surprisingly, women and their children are one of the most vulnerable demographics. Women's Daytime Drop-in Center supports these needs with special resources so families can stay safe while in transition.
Application Details: Either drop-in or call at the given hours to receive a housing assessment.
Open Hours: Monday, Wednesday, Friday: 9:00 AM - 2:00 PM (drop-in), Monday - Friday: 9:00 AM - 1:00 PM (call)

Summary: This is a drop-in center for young adults to rest during the day (shower, food, laundry, internet) and receive housing assessments for shetler referrals.
Services:
- Place to rest during the day
- Shower
- Nutritious meal
- Laundry
- Internet access
- Access to day-programming such as case management
- Referrals to additional services
Program About: There are not enough beds in the community to house all young people who experience homelessness; and sometimes, youth are not ready to engage in residential services. For those youth, we offer day outreach/wellness care, places where youth can drop in to rest during the day, shower, get a meal, do laundry, have internet access, and access to day-programming such as case management and referrals to additional services.
Organization About: Covenant House California addresses homelessness when it begins – in young adulthood, when HOPE and possibility are still strong. We EMPOWER youth to harness their strengths, that they may leave homelessness behind for good.
Application Details: Either drop-in or call at the given hours to receive a housing assessment.
Open Hours: Tuesday, Thursday: 1:00 PM - 3:0 PM (drop-in), call anytime

Organization Name: St Vincent de Paul of Alameda County
Summary: This is an overnight shelter that runs 365 days a year.
Services:
- Emergency overnight shelter for up to 45 homeless persons
- 365 days a year
Program About: The St. Vincent de Paul Shelter, in collaboration with the City of Oakland, provides emergency overnight shelter for up to 45 homeless Oakland and Emeryville persons 365 days a year. The shelter is open 7 days a week from 6pm to 8am. Walk-in spots are available on a first-come-first-served basis.
Organization About: St. Vincent de Paul of Alameda is the largest Emergency shelter in the county, open 365 days a year. Our staff and volunteers in our free dining room and community center are dedicated to providing warm meals and supplementary programs for our unhoused/housing insecure, food insecure, and impoverished neighbors in Oakland.
Application Details: Drop-in at 6:00 PM sharp to receive overnight shelter.
Open Hours: Drop-in at 6:00 PM anyday, Tuesday - Saturday: 9:00 AM - 3:00 PM (call)

Summary: This is an overnight shelter for unhoused men, including meals, clothing, hygiene kits, and showers.
Services:
- Temporary shelter
- Meals
- Clothing
- Hygiene kits
- Access to showers
Program About: Cityteam Oakland’s shelter provides a safe place for homeless men to sleep. We serve the community in Oakland by providing temporary, emergency care while sharing God’s love with the homeless. We offer hope to our clients so that they can completely transform their lives.
Organization About: CityTeam Oakland is commited to providing immediate help and support to men, women, and children struggling with food insecurity, homelessness, domestic violence, and other life-disabling circumstances and behaviors. We are here to serve, 365 days a year.
Application Details: Drop-in at 4:30 PM sharp to receive overnight shelter.

Summary: This is an emergency overnight shelter with access to a nutritious meal, a warm bed, and a clean shower.
Services:
- Nutrious meal
- Warm bed
- Clean shower
Program About: For families and individuals looking to escape extreme weather or just wanting a safe, quiet place to spend the night, emergency shelters provide a nutritious meal, a warm bed and a clean shower to those in need.
Organization About: The Salvation Army, an international movement, is an evangelical part of the universal Christian Church. Its message is based on the Bible. Its ministry is motivated by the love of God. Its mission is to preach the gospel of Jesus Christ and to meet human needs in His name without discrimination.
Application Details: Drop-in sometime during the evening to receive overnight shelter.

Summary: This is an emergency shelter for adult survivors of domestic violence with access to basic needs (meals, clothing, toiletries), mental health, and legal support.
Services:
- Case management
- Support groups
- Mental health services
- Legal/court & social service adovacy
- CalWORKs services
- Basic necessities (meals, clothing, toiletries)
- Referrals for assistance with emergency medical needs
Program About: Emergency shelter for adult survivors of domestic violence and their children is available via a residential shelter and motel program. The support services include case management, support groups, mental health services, legal/court & social service advocacy, and CalWORKs services. Basic necessities that are provided include meals, clothing, toiletries, and referrals for assistance with emergency medical needs.
Organization About: Our mission at A Safe Place is to decrease domestic violence by providing victims, survivors, and their children with a safe shelter and resources to break the cycle of violence through outreach and education to at-risk populations and diverse communities.
Application Details: Call the emergency crisis line (number provided below) for immidiate assistance.

Summary: This is an educational/employment housing program for youth ages 18-24 to build self-sufficiency skills.
Services:
- Fully subsidized housing during duration of program
- Completion of a High School Diploma or GED certificate
- Enrollment in post-secondary education or vocational training program
- Completion of industry-recognized certificates
- Seeking and securing sustainable living-wage employment
- Education planning, course selection and tutoring
- Financial aid and scholarship applications
- Leveraging existing on-campus resources
- Job search and job retention strategies
- Resume and cover letter writing
- Workplace readiness skill-building
- Career counseling
Program About: My First Place is a nationally recognized education and employment program providing housing and case management for foster youth between ages 18 and 24. Supporting foster youth entering adulthood with jobs that earn a living wage, this program fosters a sense of permanency and stability while building skills to be self-sufficient long-term.
Organization About: First Place for Youth helps foster youth build the skills they need to make a successful transition to self-sufficiency and responsible adulthood.
Application Details: Fill out this form to express interest and await further instructions: https://firstplaceforyouth.org/youth-interest-and-referral-form/.

Summary: This is a drop-in center for basic needs during the day (meals, showers, laundry, clothing, lockers, mail service, internet) and housing assessments for shelter referrals, often to their own shelter program.
Services:
- Meals, showers, laundry, clothing
- Lockers, mail services, internet access
- Daytime respite, housing support
- DMV and ID assistance
- Workforce training
- Medical and addiction referrals to partner social service agencies
Program About: Our daytime drop-in center is located at our main shelter in the heart of downtown Berkeley. We are open 7 days a week, 365 days a year to anyone in need. We offer meals, showers, laundry, free clothing, lockers, mail services, internet access, daytime respite, housing support, DMV and ID assistance, and workforce training as well as medical and addiction referrals to partner social service agencies. Come visit us!
Organization About: We provide shelter, services and resources to our unhoused Berkeley neighbors to facilitate ending homelessness in our community.
Application Details: Drop-in during provided hours to take a housing assessment for entry directly into their main shelter or receive referrals to another shelter.
Open Hours: Monday - Sunday: 8:15 AM - 11:30 AM, 1:00 PM - 4:00 PM

Summary: This is an emergency shelter to receive a warm bed, meals, shower/laundry, computers/phones, health services, and housing support.
Services:
- Clean, warm beds 
- Meals 
- Shower & laundry facilities 
- Access to computers & telephones 
- Access to housing case managers 
- Links to primary mental, dental & medical health 
- Linkages to community & mainstream services
Program About: Since 1970, Insight Housing has envisioned a world where everyone has access to affordable housing and healthy food to eat. Every day, we advocate for and partner with individuals and families experiencing housing and food insecurity, because when everyone in our community has a place to call home and enough food to eat, we all benefit.
Organization About: Our emergency shelter programs offer a safe place to stay with warm meals, for adults experiencing homelessness. It allows residents the safety and support they need to build income and skills while they seek permanent housing.
Application Details: Call the provided number for further instructions.
